results.abstract: Profile of United States national soccer player Jay DeMerit, who is back in action after having corneal transplant and is hoping to play for US in World Cup; photos (M)

headline.main: Incisions 8 Cells Deep Give Hope to U.S. Player With Career on Brink

results.snippet: Jay DeMerit, a defender who hopes to play for the U.S. in the World Cup, sustained an eye injury last year that nearly cost him his soccer career.
results.lead_paragraph: LONDON -- Jay DeMerit sat in the eye doctor's office as a machine mapped the topography of his right cornea, the dome-shaped surface that covers the iris and pupil, and helps to focus vision. A digital printout resembled a weather map with its yellows and greens and dissipating reds. ''My own Doppler radar,'' DeMerit, a central defender with the United States soccer team, said with a laugh.

results.abstract: Kalamazoo Central High School in Michigan, beating more than 1,000 public high schools in annual Race to the Top Commencement Challenge, wins Pres Barack Obama as commencement speaker; Obama salutes all six finalists; White House will choose cabinet secretary or other senior official to addresses classes at five runners-up (M)

headline.main: Michigan High School Snags Noted Hawaiian as Speaker

results.snippet: President Obama will speak at the Kalamazoo Central High School graduation. The school won a Race to the Top competition.
results.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- Proving they have more to boast of than just their alumnus Derek Jeter, the graduating Giants of Kalamazoo Central High School in Michigan have beaten more than 1,000 public high schools in a national contest of academic self-promotion. The prize: President Obama as commencement speaker. Presidents typically choose to give graduation speeches at several universities each year -- Mr. Obama was at the University of Michigan last Saturday and will be at Hampton University in Virginia this Sunday -- but rarely speak at high schools.

results.abstract: Celebrity guest hosts join World Wrestling Entertainment show 'Raw' to promote their programs and projects, adding family-friendly touch to WWE while giving celebrities platform advertising latest undertakings; photo (M)

headline.main: Celebrity Guest Hosts Find Fans, and Some Fun, in 'Raw's' Ring

results.snippet: Buzz Aldrin, Jewel, and Donald Trump are among the boldface names that have hosted World Wrestling Entertainment’s “Raw.”
results.lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. -- When Will Forte, Ryan Phillippe and Kristen Wiig were looking to promote the forthcoming comedy ''MacGruber,'' they made an early visit not to Jay Leno or David Letterman, but a live prime-time program with an audience bigger than that of either of their shows, as well as ''The View'' and ''Ellen.'' The show is ''Raw,'' a production of World Wrestling Entertainment that is shown on the USA network. In it, performers with names like the Great Khali, Triple H and Goldust climb into the ring for two hours each Monday night to do battle -- albeit (sorry, fans) in matches that are staged.

results.abstract: Neemo 14, NASA's 14th mission in nine-year-old program called NASA Extreme Environment Mission Operations, gives astronauts opportunity to work in environment similar to that on Moon or Mars; deep water project, which is located three miles off Key Largo, Fla, will focus on tasks that would be used by astronauts if they were setting up habitat on other planet; photo (M)

headline.main: Absent a Moon or Mars, Recreating Space 65 Feet Under the Sea

results.snippet: Three miles off Florida’s coast, a crew of six will go on “spacewalks,” operate a crane and perform the kind of tasks astronauts would face on another planet.
results.lead_paragraph: Astronauts will not be sent by the United States to the Moon or Mars for at least a decade, but they can still get an idea of what it would be like by living 65 feet underwater. On Monday, a crew of six, including two veteran astronauts, descended to Aquarius, an undersea laboratory next to a coral reef about three miles off Key Largo, Fla.

results.abstract: Space shuttle Atlantis, carrying crew of six, Russian docking module and critical spare parts, vaults into orbit on 12-day space station assembly mission, its 32nd and final planned flight after 25 years of service; photo (M)

headline.main: Shuttle Atlantis Lifts Off for Its Last Planned Flight

results.snippet: The space shuttle Atlantis vaulted into orbit on a 12-day space station assembly mission, the orbiter’s 32nd and final planned flight after a quarter century of service.
results.lead_paragraph: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla. -- The space shuttleAtlantis, carrying a crew of six, a Russian docking module and critical spare parts, vaulted into orbit Friday on a 12-day space station assembly mission, the orbiter's 32nd and final planned flight after a quarter century of service. With NASA bracing for the looming retirement of the shuttle fleet after a final three missions, Atlantis roared to life and rocketed away from its seaside pad at 2:20 p.m. Eastern time. The eight-and-a-half-minute ascent appeared normal as the spacecraft climbed through a partly cloudy sky, putting on a familiar, soon-to-be-missed show for area residents and tourists who turned out in droves to catch a glimpse of Atlantis's final launching.

headline.main: An Archer for the Ages Considered | Art by Michael Byers

results.snippet: Of course Robin Hood can be an astronaut. Maybe even a girl astronaut. Why not?
results.lead_paragraph: Of course Robin Hood can be an astronaut. Maybe even a girl astronaut. Why not?

results.abstract: Kate Murphy travel article on visit to Kennedy Space Center in Florida in light of fact that there are only two more launchings of space shuttles scheduled before program ends; photos (M)

headline.main: Getting Close to the Last Liftoff

results.snippet: There are only two more space shuttle launchings in Florida. Start planning now.
results.lead_paragraph: THE crowd, all facing the same direction, waits nervously. Some fiddle with cameras on tripods while others sit in camp chairs, slapping at mosquitoes and checking their cellphones for updates. A voice comes over a loudspeaker: ''T minus 9 minutes and counting.'' After hours of excruciating anticipation, the final checks for the space shuttle launching have been made and all systems are go. Parents chase after small children dressed up in orange astronaut suits who can no longer contain their excitement. There is a collective gasp at T minus 2 minutes, 55 seconds, when the so-called ''beanie cap,'' or oxygen vent arm, retracts, making it appear that the shuttle is tipping its hat in farewell. T minus zero and there is a brilliant burst of billowing flame and a thunderous roar that shakes the ground and vibrates vital organs.

results.abstract: Considered Art drawing of Robin Hood as astronaut (S)
results.snippet: Of course Robin Hood can be an astronaut. Maybe even a girl astronaut. Why not. He has already been a Chicago gangster (that would be ''Robin and the 7 Hoods,'' with Frank Sinatra as Robbo) and a duck (that would be Daffy). Lots of actors have played...
results.lead_paragraph: Of course Robin Hood can be an astronaut. Maybe even a girl astronaut. Why not. He has already been a Chicago gangster (that would be ''Robin and the 7 Hoods,'' with Frank Sinatra as Robbo) and a duck (that would be Daffy). Lots of actors have played him, most immortally Errol Flynn, but Douglas Fairbanks, Kevin Costner and Sean Connery (not the laddish version) have also taken an arrow from the quiver. Last week, Ridley Scott's ''Robin Hood'' opened, with Russell Crowe as Robin. The film is something of a prequel to the tale of the band that roams the Sherwood Forest. But it doesn't matter who inhabits the shape-shifting myth or what the setting. There's apparently a Robin Hood for everyone, in these hard times or any other. You don't have to be a socialist intent on relieving the rich of their plunder and redistributing it to the deserving poor. You can be a libertarian or a tea partier, relieving a sprawling government of its extra power and returning it to the people. In the future, perhaps when most of the world is ocean, there might be a band of mermen who raid yachts to provision our dinghies and fatten up the obesity-free friar. Just guessing.

headline.main: Softbank to Help Twitter Get Even Bigger in Japan

results.snippet: The cellphone carrier Softbank announced new handsets designed to link to the micro-blogging site, part of a concerted effort to get a piece of America’s tech savvy.
results.lead_paragraph: TOKYO -- Twitter is set to get a big boost in Japan, one of its biggest and fastest-growing markets, after the Japanese cellphone carrier Softbank on Tuesday announced new handsets designed to link to the microblogging site, part of a major effort by Softbank to get a piece of America's tech savvy. Twitter has taken off in a big way here in the past two years, fanned by media exposure and the use of the service by a flurry of celebrities: Prime Minister Yukio Hatoyama tweets frequently, as does the astronaut and national hero Soichi Noguchi, who tweets from the International Space Station.

results.snippet: A selected guide to events for and about children in New YorkCity.
results.lead_paragraph: FOR CHILDREN ADOPTAPALOOZA (Saturday) This event presents an opportunity to make a new best friend -- and these potential pals don't care whether you're cool or how you dress or how good you are at sports. They're the many dogs and cats at this first annual pet adoption celebration from the Mayor's Alliance for NYC's Animals. In addition to a host of friendly creatures needing new homes, the day will include a doggie costume contest (details on the Web site), a dog agility demonstration, ask-the-vet and ask-the-trainer sessions, a raffle and a chance to be photographed with your pet. From 11 a.m. to 4 p.m., Washington Square Park, Greenwich Village, animalalliancenyc.org/adoptapalooza; free.

results.abstract: Team of amateur sky watchers has pierced veil of secrecy surrounding debut flight of nation's first robotic spacecraft; has found clues suggesting military craft is engaged in development of spy satellites rather than space weapons, as some experts had theorized but Pentagon strongly denies assertions (M)

headline.main: Surveillance Is Suspected As Main Role Of Spacecraft

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: UNITED STATES DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES

results.snippet: Amateur sky watchers have pierced the veil of secrecy surrounding the debut flight of a robotic spaceplane.
results.lead_paragraph: A team of amateur sky watchers has pierced the veil of secrecy surrounding the debut flight of the nation's first robotic spaceplane, finding clues that suggest the military craft is engaged in the development of spy satellites rather than space weapons, which some experts have suspected but the Pentagon strongly denies. Last month, the unmanned successor to the space shuttle blasted off from Florida on its debut mission but attracted little public notice because no one knew where it was going or what it was doing. The spaceship, known as the X-37B, was shrouded in operational secrecy, even as civilian specialists reported that it might go on mysterious errands for as long as nine months before zooming back to earth and touching down on a California runway.

Last month, the unmanned successor to the space shuttle blasted off from Florida on its debut mission but attracted little public notice because no one knew where it was going or what it was doing. results.abstract: Popular ABC program Dancing With the Stars, which set ratings records in its 10th season, had lowest season-finale audience when Nicole Scherzinger and partner Derek Hough won competition; two-hour Monday night performance episodes have averaged 21.6 million viewers, up from 18.2 million last fall; photo (M)

headline.main: Fewer Viewers for This Year's 'Dancing With the Stars' Finale

results.snippet: The ABC dance competition had low numbers for its finale but set ratings records this season, its 10th.
results.lead_paragraph: ''Dancing With the Stars'' had its lowest season-finale audience when Nicole Scherzinger and her professional partner Derek Hough were awarded the disco ball trophy on Tuesday night. Yet the show's Monday night performances have never been more popular. ''Dancing With the Stars,'' in its 10th season, set ratings records for ABC this spring, running counter to the declines that most older shows experience.

results.snippet: A guide to events for and by children and families in the New York area.
results.lead_paragraph: FOR CHILDREN 'The Crimson Wing' Skeptics who argue against the possibility of extraterrestrial life have probably never considered Lake Natron. Part of Earth - northern Tanzania - this saline and sulfurous body, in a volcanic environment where temperatures reach 130 degrees, would seem to be one of the most uninhabitable places imaginable. But if life can make it there, can't it make it anywhere?

results.abstract: Telemedicine, spurred by health care trends and technological advances, is growing into mainstream industry; needs of patients in areas where primary care doctors are scarce is converging with advances that include lower costs for video-conferencing equipment, more high-speed communications links by satellite, and greater ability to work securely over Internet; telemedical industry is growing by almost 10 percent annually to more than $500 million in revenue in 2010; photos (M)

headline.main: The Doctor Will See You Now. Please Log On.

results.snippet: Advances in video technology and a need to reduce medical costs have made interactive telemedicine a growing business.
results.lead_paragraph: ONE day last summer, Charlie Martin felt a sharp pain in his lower back. But he couldn't jump into his car and rush to the doctor's office or the emergency room: Mr. Martin, a crane operator, was working on an oil rig in the South China Sea off Malaysia. He could, though, get in touch with a doctor thousands of miles away, via two-way video. Using an electronic stethoscope that a paramedic on the rig held in place, Dr. Oscar W. Boultinghouse, an emergency medicine physician in Houston, listened to Mr. Martin's heart.

results.abstract: Annual World Science Festival in New York will feature orchestral world premiere of Icarus, gala celebrating science at Alice Tully Hall and appearance by Cambridge University cosmologist Stephen Hawking (M)

headline.main: The Cosmos and the Culture Converge at a Science Festival

results.snippet: A black hole rolls toward New York.     Has the Large Hadron Collider finally done its worst?
